>>1. A 3-phase synchronous generator is operating at a constant load while the excitation is adjusted to give unity pf current. If the excitation is now increased, the pf will<< ( ) become leading (x) become lagging ( ) remain at unity ( ) become zero
>>2) A synchronous motor with negligible armature resistance runs at a load angle of 20⁰ at rated frequency. If supply frequency is increased by 10%, keeping other parameters constant, the new load angle will be<< ( ) 16⁰ ( ) 18⁰ (x) 20⁰ ( ) 22⁰
>>3) The constant speed of a synchronous motor can be changed to new fixed value by<< (x) changing the frequency of supply ( ) changing the applied voltage ( ) changing the load ( ) interchanging any two phases
>>4) A synchronous motor working on leading power factor and not driving any mechanical, is known<< ( ) synchronous induction motor ( ) spinning motor (x) synchronous condenser ( ) none of the above
>>5) In a synchronous motor if the back emf generated in the armature at no load is approximately equal to the applied voltage, then<< ( ) the excitation is said to be zero percent ( ) the motor is said to be fully loaded (x) the excitation is said to be 100% ( ) the torque generated is maximum
